citeinfo.title: Building Outlines, Tompkins County NY, 2005
citeinfo.othercit: Derived from 2002 Tompkins County orthoimagery provided by NYS Office of Cyber Security & Critical Infrastructure Coordination

descript.abstract: Building polygons representing houses, businesses, mobile homes, barns, silos and other buildings that could be determined from aerial photography, using photogrammetric mapping technologies and HouseDiff feature extraction process.
descript.purpose: This data set is intended for use as a reference map layer for GIS maps and applications.

idinfo.useconst: The following statement must be included with any products that use or are derived from this data set: Data contained in this product was originally produced by NYSEG, the NYS Office of Cyber Security & Critical Infrastructure Coordination Program, The City of Ithaca, Hitachi Software and the Tompkins County Information Technology Services GIS Division and may not be reproduced or redistributed without the express written consent of the originators. The originators do not warrant the accuracy or completeness of the information portrayed by the data or its suitability for any specific use.
idinfo.datacred: Tompkins County ITS GIS Division. Building data outside the City of Ithaca vectorized by Hitachi Software. Original orthoimagery (Color Infrared) from the NYS Office of Cyber Security & Critical Infrastructure Coordination, 2002. City of Ithaca data originally produced by NYSEG and subsequently updated by the City of Ithaca Planning Department.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.1.0.722

dataqual.logic: All polygons in this dataset is part of an ArcGIS geodatabase and consistency is maintained using ArcGIS map topology and geodatabase topology rules, then exported to a shapefile. Error checking is performed in the source data set. Please keep in mind that this dataset is not field checked and as with any features extraction process there are going to be polygons that looked like buildings on an aerial photo but are not in the field.
dataqual.complete: Complete featureclass or shapefile for the entire County. However, keep in mind that the City of Ithaca portion of this dataset was not part of the Hitachi HouseDiff process which acquired footprints from 2002 aerial photos.

horizpa.horizpar: Varies, depending on source of building footprint. The accuracy of the data set range from the accuracy of the 1991 Tompkins County Planimetric Base Map series data in the City to the accuracy of the 2002 aerial photos.

procstep.procdesc: In June of 2005, Tompkins County ITS GIS Division entered into a contractual service agreement with Hitachi Software to provide building footprint data from 2002 infrared Ortho Imagery using the Hitachi HouseDiff method. See <http://www.hgiis.com/services/serv_housediff.html> for more info on HouseDiff. The result of this contract was a shapefile of building footprints with 44,711 features received by Tompkins County on August 3, 2005. As spelled out in the contract Tompkins County had 30 days after receipt to review the building footprints for errors and to provide feedback to Hitachi Software before the deadline. This deadline was extended to September 30, 2005 via a letter from Hitachi Software received by Tompkins County on September 2, 2005. The two parties agreed that feedback would be provided in the form of a point shapefile consisting of two fields; "status" and "comment." The values for the "status" field are denoted in the enumerated domain values for the "status" field under the Entity Attribute section of the feedback point metadata. Comments were also added when necessary. The data was derived via manual inspection of each image tile from the countywide orthoimagery dataset with the exception of those tiles covering the City of Ithaca. Photographs were used by the Tompkins County review team to detect differences in shape and to help with missing buildings where applicable. The building dataset was processed by Hitachi on a parcel-by-parcel basis using 2002 County tax parcel data and original 1991-1995 Planimetric Building footprint data. Feedback (point shapefile) was sent to Hitachi, and a final building footprint dataset with changes from the feedback process was received on October 5, 2005. These buildings were manually inspected by grid to make sure that the buildings correlating to each feedback point were processed. The resulting data file was copied and merged with the buildings covering the City of Ithaca that are from the original 1991-1995 Planimetric building footprint data.

enttyp.enttypd: Polygons representing houses, businesses, mobile homes and other buildings that could be determined from aerial photography.

attr.attrdef: Unique ID number assigned by software calculation important for ArcIMS applications.
Concatenation of SWIS code, "-", and the PRINTKEY field from the parcel polygon on which the building polygon is located.

attrdomv.udom: Concatenation of SWIS code, "-", and the PRINTKEY field from the parcel polygon on which the building polygon is located.

attr.attrdef: A mathematical calculation of the size of the building polygon feature, measured in square units.
The sum of the lengths of the sides of the building polygon as calculated by the software.
Length of feature in internal units.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

distinfo.distliab: Cornell University provides these geographic data "as is". Cornell University makes no guarantee or warranty concerning the accuracy of information contained in the geographic data. The burden for determining fitness for use lies entirely with the user. Although these files have been processed successfully on computers at Cornell University, no warranty is made by Cornell University regarding the use of these data on any other system, nor does the fact of distribution constitute or imply any such warranty.

Tompkins County does not warrant the accuracy or completeness of the information portrayed in this data. The end user of the data and products derived from it agrees to accept the data "as is", with the full knowledge that errors and omissions may exist.
